column1: 限りとてわかるる道のかなしきにいかまほしきは命なりけり
column2:
I leave you, to go the road we all must go. 
The road I would choose, if only I could, is the other.

column1: 宮城野の露吹き結ぶ風の音に小萩が本を思ひこそやれ
column2:
At the sound of the wind, bringing dews to Miyagi Plain, 
I think of the tender hagi* upon the moor.

column1: 鈴虫の声の限りを尽くしても長き夜あかずふる涙かな
column2:
The autumn night is too short to contain my tears
Though songs of bell cricket weary, fall into silence.

column1: いとゞしく虫の音しげき浅茅生に露をき添ふる雲の上人
column2:
Sad are the insect songs among the reeds. 
More sadly yet falls the dew from above the clouds.

column1: 荒き風ふせぎし陰の枯しより小萩がうへぞ静心なき
column2:
The tree that gave them shelter has withered and died. 
One fears for the plight of the hagi shoots beneath.

column1: 尋ねゆくまぼろしもがなつてにても玉のありかをそこと知るべく
column2:
And will no wizard search her out for me, 
That even he may tell me where she is?

column1: 雲のうへも涙に暮るる秋の月いかで住らむ浅茅生の宿
column2:
Tears dim the moon, even here above the clouds. 
Dim must it be in that lodging among the reeds.

column1: いときなき初元結ひに長き世を契る心は結びこめつや
column2:
The boyish locks are now bound up, a man's. 
And do we tie a lasting bond for his future?

column1: 結びつる心も深き元結ひに濃き紫の色しあせずは
column2:
Fast the knot which the honest heart has tied. 
May lavender, the hue of the troth, be as fast.

column1: 手をおりてあひ見し事をかぞふればこれひとつやは君がうきふし
column2:
I count them over, the many things between us. 
One finger does not, alas, count the sum of your failures.

column1: うきふしを心ひとつにかぞへきてこや君が手をわかるべきおり
column2:
I have counted them up myself, be assured, my failures. 
For one bitten finger must all be bitten away?

column1: 琴の音も月もえならぬ宿ながらつれなき人を引きやとめける
column2:
Uncommonly fine this house, for moon, for koto. 
Does it bring to itself indifferent callers as well?

column1: 木枯らしに吹きあはすめる笛の音を引きとゞむべきことの葉ぞなき
column2:
No match the leaves for the angry winter winds. 
Am I to detain the flute that joins those winds?

column1: 山がつの垣ほ荒るともおりおりにあはれはかけよなでしこの露
column2:
The fence of the mountain rustic may fall to the ground. 
Rest gently. O dew, upon the wild carnation.

column1: 咲きまじる色はいづれとわかねども猶常夏にしくものぞなき
column2:
No bloom in this wild array would I wish to slight. 
But dearest of all to me is the wild carnation.

column1: うちはらふ袖も露けきとこなつにあらし吹きそふ秋も来にけり
column2:
Dew wets the sleeve that brushes the wild carnation. 
The tempest rages. Now comes autumn too.

column1: さゝがにのふるまひしるき夕暮れにひるま過ぐせと言ふがあやなさ
column2:
The spider must have told you I would come. 
Then why am I asked to keep company with garlic?

column1: 逢ふことの夜をし隔てぬ中ならばひるまも何かまばゆからまし
column2:
Were we two who kept company every night, 
What would be wrong with garlic in the daytime?

column1: つれなきをうらみもはてぬしのゝめにとりあへぬまでおどろかすらむ
column2:
Why must they startle with their dawn alarums 
When hours are yet required to thaw the ice?

column1: 身のうさを嘆くにあかで明くる夜はとりかさねてぞねも泣かれける
column2:
Day has broken without an end to my tears, 
To my cries of sorrow are added the calls of the cocks.

column1: 見し夢をあふ夜ありやと嘆くまに目さへあはでぞころも経にける
column2:
I yearn to dream again the dream of that night. 
The nights go by in lonely wakefulness.

column1: はゝき木の心を知らで園原の道にあやなくまどひぬるかな
column2:
I wander lost in the Sonohara moorlands, 
For I did not know the deceiving ways of the broom tree.

column1: 数ならぬ伏屋に生ふる名のうさにあるにもあらず消ゆるはゝ木ゝ
column2:
Here and not here. I lie in my shabby hut. 
Would that I might like the broom tree vanish away.

column1: 空蝉の身をかへてける木のもとになを人がらのなつかしきかな
column2:
Beneath a tree, a locust's empty shell. 
Sadly I muse upon the shell of a lady.

column1: 空蝉の羽にをく露の木がくれて忍び忍びに濡るる袖かな
column2: The dew upon the fragile locust wing

column1: 心あてにそれかとぞ見る白露の光添へたる夕顔の花
column2: Is lost among the leaves. Lost are my tears.

column1: 寄りてこそそれかとも見めたそかれにほのぼの見つる花の夕顔
column2:
Come a bit nearer, please. Then might you know 
Whose was the evening face so dim in the twilight.

column1: 咲花にうつるてふ名はつつめどもおらで過ぎうきけさの朝顔
column2:
Though loath to be taxed with seeking fresher blooms, 
I feel impelled to pluck this morning glory.

column1: 朝霧の晴れ間も待たぬけしきにて花に心をとめぬとぞ見る
column2:
In haste to plunge into the morning mists, 
You seem to have no heart for the blossoms here.

column1: 優婆塞が行ふ道をしるべにて来む世も深き契たがふな
column2:
This pious one shall lead us on our way 
As we plight our troth for all the lives to come.

column1: 先の世の契知らるる身のうさに行く末かねて頼みがたさよ
column2:
So heavy the burden I bring with me from the past, 
I doubt that I should make these vows for the future.

column1: いにしへもかくやは人のまどひけん我まだ知らぬ篠の目の道
column2:
And did it confuse them too, the men of old, 
This road through the dawn, for me so new and strange?

column1: 山の端の心も知らでゆく月はうはの空にて影や絶えなむ
column2:
And is the moon, unsure of the hills it approaches, 
Foredoomed to lose its way in the empty skies?

column1: 夕露に紐とく花は玉鉾のたよりに見えしえにこそありけれ
column2:
Because of one chance meeting by the wayside 
The flower now opens in the evening dew.

column1: 光ありと見し夕顔のうは露はたそかれ時のそら目なりけり
column2:
The face seemed quite to shine in the evening dew, 
But I was dazzled by the evening light.

column1: 見し人の煙を雲とながむれば夕べの空もむつましきかな
column2:
One sees the clouds as smoke that rose from the pyre, 
And suddenly the evening sky seems nearer.

column1: 問はぬをもなどかと問はでほど経るにいかばかりかは思ひ乱るる
column2:
Time goes by, you ask not why I ask not. 
Think if you will how lonely a life is mine.

column1: 空蝉の世はうき物と知りにしをまた言の葉にかかる命よ
column2:
Hollow though it was, the shell of the locust 
Gave me strength to face a gloomy world.

column1: ほのかにも軒端の萩を結ばずは露のかことを何にかけまし
column2:
I bound them loosely, the reeds beneath the eaves, 
And reprove them now for having come undone.

column1: ほのめかす風につけても下萩のなかばは霜に結ぼほれつつ
column2:
The wind brings words, all softly, to the reed, 
And the under leaves are nipped again by the frost.

column1: 泣く泣くもけふはわが結ふ下紐をいづれの世にかとけて見るべき
column2:
I weep and weep as today I tie this cord. 
It will be untied in an unknown world to come.

column1: 逢ふまでの形見ばかりと見しほどにひたすら袖の朽ちにけるかな
column2:
A keepsake till we meet again,I had hoped,
And see,my tears have rotted the sleeves away.

column1: 蝉の羽もたちかへてける夏衣かへすを見ても音は泣かれけり
column2:
Autumn comes, the wings of the locust are shed. 
A summer robe returns, and I weep aloud.

column1: 過ぎにしもけふ別るるも二道に行くかた知らぬ秋の暮かな
column2:
The one has gone, to the other I say farewell. 
They go their unknown ways. The end of autumn.

column1: をひたたむありかも知らぬ若草ををくらす露ぞ消えんそらなき
column2:
Are these tender grasses to grow without the dew 
Which holds itself back from the heavens that would receive it?

column1: 初草の生い行くゑも知らぬ間にいかでか露の消えんとすらむ
column2:
It cannot be that the dew will vanish away 
Ere summer comes to these early grasses of spring.

column1: 初草の若葉のうへを見つるより旅寝の袖も露ぞかはかぬ
column2:
Since first the wanderer glimpsed the fresh young grasses 
His sleeves have known no respite from the dew.

column1: 枕ゆふこよひばかりの露けさを深山の苔にくらべざらなむ
column2:
The dew of a night of travel―do not compare it 
With the dew that soaks the sleeves of the mountain dweller.

column1: 吹まよふ深山おろしに夢さめて涙もよほす滝のをとかな
column2:
A wind strays down from the hills to end my dream, 
And tears well forth at these voices upon the waters.

column1: さしぐみに袖ぬらしける山水にすめる心はさはぎやはする
column2:
These waters wet your sleeves. Our own are dry, 
And tranquil our hearts, washed clean by mountain waters.

column1: 宮人に行て語らむ山桜風よりさきに来ても見るべく
column2:
I shall say to my city friends: 'Make haste to see 
Those mountain blossoms. The winds may see them first.

column1: 優曇華の花待ち得たる心ちして深山桜に目こそ移らね
column2:
In thirty hundreds of years it blooms but once. 
My eyes have seen it, and spurn these mountain cherries.

column1: 奥山の松の戸ぼそをまれに明てまだ見ぬ花の顔を見るかな
column2:
My mountain door of pine has opened briefly 
To see a radiant flower not seen before.

column1: 夕まぐれほのかに花の色を見てけさは霞の立ちぞわづらふ
column2:
Having come upon an evening blossom, 
The mist is loath to go with the morning sun.

column1: まことにや花のあたりは立ちうきと霞むる空のけしきをも見む
column2:
Can we believe the mist to be so reluctant? 
We shall watch the morning sky for signs of truth.

column1: 面影は身をも離れず山桜心の限りとめて来しかど
column2:
The mountain blossoms are here beside me still. 
All of myself I left behind with them.

column1: 嵐吹おのへの桜散らぬ間を心とめけるほどのはかなさ
column2:
Brief as the time till the autumn tempests come 
To scatter the flowers―so brief your thoughts of her.

column1: あさか山浅くも人を思はぬになど山の井のかけ離るらむ
column2:
No Shallow Spring, this heart of mine believe me. 
And why must the mountain spring then seem so distant?

column1: 汲みそめてくやしと聞きし山の井の浅きながらや影を見ゆべき
column2:
You drink at the mountain stream, your thoughts turn elsewhere. 
Do you hope to see the image you thus disturb?

column1: 見ても又逢ふ夜まれなる夢のうちにやがてまぎるるわが身ともがな
column2:
So few and scattered the nights, so few the dreams. 
Would that the dream tonight might take me with it.

column1: 世語りに人や伝へんたぐひなくうき身を覚めぬ夢になしても
column2:
Were I to disappear in the last of dreams 
Would yet my name live on in infamy?

column1: いはけなき鶴の一声聞きしより葦間になづむ舟ぞえならぬ
column2:
Seeking to follow the call of the nestling crane 
The open boat is lost among the reeds.

column1: 手に摘みていつしかも見む紫の根に通ひける野辺の若草
column2:
I long to have it, to bring it in from the moor, 
The lavender that shares its roots with another.

column1: あしわかの浦にみるめはかたくともこは立ちながら返る波かは
column2:
Rushes hide the sea grass at Wakanoura. 
Must the waves that seek it out turn back to sea?

column1: 寄る波の心も知らでわかの浦に玉藻なびかんほどぞ浮きたる
column2:
The grass at Wakanoura were rash indeed 
To follow waves that go it knows not whither.

column1: あさぼらけ霧立つ空のまよひにも行過ぎがたき妹が門かな
column2:
Lost though I seem to be in the mists of dawn, 
I see your gate, and cannot pass it by.

column1: 立ちとまり霧のまがきの過ぎうくは草の戸ざしに障りしもせじ
column2:
So difficult to pass? Then do come in. 
No obstacle at all, this gate of grass.

column1: ねは見ねどあはれとぞ思ふ武蔵野の露分けわぶる草のゆかりを
column2:
Thick are the dewy grasses of Musashi, 
Near this grass to the grass I cannot have.

column1: かこつべきゆへを知らねばおぼつかないかなる草のゆかりなるらん
column2:
I do not know what it is that makes you sigh. 
And whatever grass can it be I am so near to?

column1: もろともに大内山は出でつれど入るかた見せぬいさよひの月
column2:
Though together we left the heights of Mount Ouchi, 
This moon of the sixteenth night has secret ways.

column1: さとわかぬかげをば見れどゆく月のいるさの山をたれかたづぬる
column2:
It sheds its rays impartially here and there, 
And who should care what mountain it sets behind?

column1: いくそたび君がしじまに負けぬらんものな言ひそといはぬたのみに
column2:
Countless times your silence has silenced me. 
My hope is that you hope for something better.

column1: かねつきてとぢめむことはさすがにてこたえまうきぞかつはあやなき
column2:
I cannot ring a bell enjoining silence. 
Silence, strangely, is my only answer.

column1: いはぬをもいふにまさると知りながらをしこめたるは苦しかりけり
column2:
Silence. I know, is finer by far than words. 
Its sister, dumbness, at times is rather painful.

column1: 夕霧のはるるけしきもまだ見ぬにいぶせさそふるよひの雨かな
column2:
The gloomy evening mists have not yet cleared, 
And now comes rain, to bring still darker gloom.

column1: 晴れぬ夜の月まつ里を思ひやれおなじ心にながめせずとも
column2:
My village awaits the moon on a cloudy night. 
You may imagine the gloom, though you do not share it.

column1: 朝日さす軒のたるひはとけながらなどかつららのむすぼほるらむ
column2:
In the morning sun the icicles melt at the eaves. 
Why must the ice below refuse to melt?

column1: ふりにける頭の雪を見る人もおとらずぬらすあさの袖かな
column2:
My sleeves are no less wet in the morning snow
Than the sleeves of this man who wears a crown snow.

column1: からころも君がこころのつらければたもとはかくぞそぼちつつのみ
column2:
Always, always my sleeve is wet like these. 
Wet because you are so very cold.

column1: なつかしき色ともなしになににこのすゑつむ花を袖にふれけむ
column2:
Red is not. I fear, my favorite color. 
Then why did I let the safflower stain my sleeve?

column1: くれなゐのひと花ごろも薄くともひたすらくたす名をしたてずは
column2:
This robe of pink, but new to the dyer's hand: 
Do not soil it, please, beyond redemption.

column1: あはぬ夜をへだつるなかのころもでに重ねていとど見もし見よとや
column2:
Layer on layer, the nights when I do not see you. 
And now these garments-layers yet thicker between us?

column1: くれなゐの花ぞあやなくうとまるる梅の立枝はなつかしけれど
column2:
The red of the florid nose fails somehow to please, 
Though one longs for red on these soaring branches of plum.

column1: もの思ふにたち舞ふべくもあらぬ身の袖うちふりし心知りきや
column2: Through the waving, dancing sleeves could you see a heart  So stormy that it wished but to be still?"
column3:
Through the waving, dancing sleeves could you see a heart 
So stormy that it wished but to be still?"

column1: から人の袖ふることはとをけれど立ちゐにつけてあはれとは見き
column2: Of waving Chinese sleeves I cannot speak.  Each step, each motion, touched me to the heart.
column3:
Of waving Chinese sleeves I cannot speak. 
Each step, each motion, touched me to the heart.

column1: いかさまにむかし結べるちぎりにてこの世にかかる中のへだてぞ
column2: What legacy do we bring from former lives  That loneliness should be our lot in this one?
column3:
What legacy do we bring from former lives 
That loneliness should be our lot in this one?

column1: 見ても思ふ見ぬはたいかに嘆くらむこや世の人のまどふてふ闇
column2: Sad at seeing the child, sad at not seeing.  The heart of the father, the mother, lost in darkness.
column3:
Sad at seeing the child, sad at not seeing. 
The heart of the father, the mother, lost in darkness.

column1: よそへつつ見るに心はなぐさまで露けさまさるなでしこの花
column2: It resembles you. I think, this wild carnation,  Weighted with my tears as with the dew.
column3:
It resembles you. I think, this wild carnation, 
Weighted with my tears as with the dew.

column1: 袖ぬるる露のゆかりと思ふにも猶うとまれぬやまとなでしこ
column2: It serves you ill, the Japanese carnation,  To make you weep. Yet I shall not forsake it.
column3:
It serves you ill, the Japanese carnation, 
To make you weep. Yet I shall not forsake it.

column1: 君し来ば手なれの駒に刈り餌はむさかりすぎたる下葉なりとも
column2: Sere and withered though these grasses be,  They are ready for your pony, should you come.
column3:
Sere and withered though these grasses be, 
They are ready for your pony, should you come.

column1: 笹分けば人やとがめむいつとなく駒なつくめる森の木がくれ
column2: Were mine to part the low bamboo at your grove,  It would fear to be driven away by other ponies.
column3:
Were mine to part the low bamboo at your grove, 
It would fear to be driven away by other ponies.

column1: 立ち濡るる人しもあらじ東屋にうたてもかかる雨そそきかな
column2: No one waits in the rain at my eastern cottage.  Wet are the sleeves of the one who waits within.
column3:
No one waits in the rain at my eastern cottage. 
Wet are the sleeves of the one who waits within.

column1: 人妻はあなわづらはし東屋の真屋のあまりもなれじとぞ思ふ
column2: On closer terms with the eaves of your eastern cottage  I would not be, for someone is there before me.
column3:
On closer terms with the eaves of your eastern cottage 
I would not be, for someone is there before me.

column1: つつむめる名やもり出でん引きかはしかくほころぶる中の衣に
column2: Your fickle name so wants to be known to the world  That it bursts its way through this warmly disputed garment.
column3:
Your fickle name so wants to be known to the world 
That it bursts its way through this warmly disputed garment.

column1: かくれなき物と知る知る夏衣きたるをうすき心とぞ見る
column2: You taunt me, sir, with being a spectacle When you know full well that your own summer robes are showy.
column3:
You taunt me, sir, with being a spectacle
When you know full well that your own summer robes are showy.

column1: うらみても言ふかひぞなき立かさね引きてかへりしなみのなごりに
column2: I need not comment now upon my feelengs. The waves that came in together went out together,
column3:
I need not comment now upon my feelengs.
The waves that came in together went out together,

column1: あらだちし浪に心はさはがねど寄せけむ磯をいかがうらみぬ
column2: I shall not complain of the wave that came raging in,  But of the welcoming strand I must complain.
column3:
I shall not complain of the wave that came raging in, 
But of the welcoming strand I must complain.

column1: 中絶えばかごとやおふとあやふさにはなだの帯をとりてだに見ず
column2: Not to be charged with having taken your take,  I return this belt of indigo undamaged.
column3:
Not to be charged with having taken your take, 
I return this belt of indigo undamaged.

column1: 君にかくひきとられぬる帯なればかくて絶えぬる中とかこたむ
column2: I doubted not that you took my indigo belt, And charge you now with taking the lady too.
column3:
I doubted not that you took my indigo belt,
And charge you now with taking the lady too.

column1: 尽きもせぬ心の闇にくるるかな雲井に人を見るにつけても
column2: I see her disappear behind the clouds  And am left to grope my way through deepest darkness.
column3:
I see her disappear behind the clouds 
And am left to grope my way through deepest darkness.

column1: おほかたに花のすがたを見ましかば露も心のおかれましやは
column2:
Could I see the blossom as other blossoms, 
Then would there be no dew to cloud my heart.

column1: 深き夜のあはれを知るも入月のおぼろけならぬ契とぞおもふ
column2:
Late in the night we enjoy a misty moon. 
There is nothing misty about the bond between us.

column1: うき身世にやがて消えなばたづねても草の原をば問はじとや思ふ
column2:
Were the lonely one to vanish quite away, 
Would you go to the grassy moors to ask her name?

column1: いづれぞと露のやどりを分かむまに小笹が原に風もこそ吹け
column2:
I wish to know whose dewy lodge it is 
Ere winds blow past the bamboo-tangled moor.

column1: 世に知らぬ心ちこそすれ有明の月のゆくゑをそらにまがへて
column2:
I had not known the sudden loneliness 
Of having it vanish, the moon in the sky of dawn.

column1: わが宿の花しなべての色ならばなにかはさらに君を待たまし
column2:
If these blossoms of mine were of the common sort, 
Would I press you so to come and look upon them?

column1: 梓弓いるさの山にまどふ哉ほのみし月のかげや見ゆると
column2:
I wander lost on Arrow Mount and ask: 
May I not see the moon I saw so briefly?

column1: 心いる方ならませば弓張りの月なき空にまよはましやは
column2:
Only the flighty, the less than serious ones, 
Are left in the skies when the longbow moon is gone

column1: 影をのみみたらし河のつれなきに身のうきほどぞいとど知らるる
column2:
A distant glimpse of the River of Lustration. 
His coldness is the measure of my sorrow.

column1: はかりなき千尋の底の海松ぶさの生ひゆくすゑはわれのみぞ見む
column2:
Mine it shall be, rich as the grasses beneath 
The fathomless sea, the thousand-fathomed sea.

column1: 千尋ともいかでか知らむさだめなく満ち干る潮ののどけからぬに
column2:
It may indeed be a thousand fathoms deep. 
How can I know, when it restlessly comes and goes?

column1: はかなしや人のかざせるあふひゆへ神のゆるしのけふを待ちける
column2:
Ah, the fickleness! It summoned me 
To a meeting, the heartvine now worn by another.

column1: かざしける心ぞあだに思ほゆる八十氏人になべてあふひを
column2:
Yes, fickleness, this vine of the day of meeting, 
Available to all the eighty clans.

column1: くやしくもかざしけるかな名のみして人だのめなる草葉ばかりを
column2:
Vine of meeting indeed! A useless weed, 
A mouthing, its name, of empty promises.

column1: 袖ぬるる恋ぢとかつは知りながら下り立つ田子の身づからぞうき
column2:
I go down the way of love and dampen my sleeves, 
And go yet further, into the muddy fields.

column1: 浅みにや人は下り立つわが方は身もそぼつまで深き恋ぢを
column2:
You only dip into the shallow waters, 
And I quite disappear into the slough?

column1: なげきわび空に乱るるわが魂をむすびとどめよしたがへのつま
column2:
Bind the hem of my robe, to keep it within, 
The grieving soul that has wandered through the skies.

column1: のぼりぬる煙はそれとわかねどもなべて雲ゐのあはれなる哉
column2:
>Might these clouds be the smoke that mounts from her pyre? 
They fill my heart with feelings too deep for words.

column1: 限りあれば薄墨衣あさけれど涙ぞ袖をふちとなしける
column2:
Weeds obey rules Mine are the shallower hue. 
But tears plunge my sleeves Into the deepest wells.

column1: 人の世をあはれときくも露けきにをくるる袖を思ひこそやれ
column2:
I too am in tears, at the thought of her sad, short life. 
Moist the sleeves of you whom she left behind.

column1: とまる身も消えしもおなじ露の世に心をくらむほどぞはかなき
column2:
We go, we stay, alike of this world of dew. 
We should not let it have such a hold upon us.

column1: 雨となりしぐるる空のうき雲をいづれの方とわきてながめむ
column2:
Is she the rain? Where in these stormy skies, 
To which of these brooding clouds may I look to find her?

column1: 見し人の雨となりにし雲井さへいとど時雨にかきくらす比
column2:
It is a time of storms when even the clouds 
To which my lady has risen are blotted away.

column1: 草枯れのまがきに残るなでしこを別れし秋のかたみとぞ見る
column2:
Carnations at the wintry hedge remind me 
Of an autumn which we leave too far behind.

column1: いまも見てなかなか袖をくたすかな垣ほ荒れにし大和なでしこ
column2:
I see them, and my sleeves are drenched afresh, 
The wild carnations at the wasted hedge.

column1: わきてこの暮れこそ袖は露けけれ物おもふ秋はあまたへぬれど
column2:
Many a desolate autumn have I known, 
But never have my tears flowed as tonight.

column1: 秋霧にたちをくれぬと聞きしより時雨る空もいかがとぞ思ふ
column2:
I knew that the autumn mists had faded away, 
And looked for you in the stormy autumn skies.

column1: なき玉ぞいとどかなしき寝し床のあくがれがたき心ならひに
column2:
Weeping beside the pillow of one who is gone, 
I may not go, so strong the ties, myself.

column1: 君なくて塵積もりぬるとこなつの露うち払ひいく夜寝ぬらむ
column2:
The dust piles on the now abandoned bed. 
How many dew-drenched nights have I slept alone!

column1: あやなくもへだてけるかな夜を重ねさすがになれし夜の衣を
column2:
Many have been the nights we have spent together 
Purposelessly, these coverlets between us.

column1: あまた年けふあらためし色ごろもきては涙ぞふるここちする
column2:
Yet once again I put on robes for the new, 
And tears are falling for all that went with the old.

column1: あたらしき年ともいはずふる物はふりぬる人の涙なりけり
column2:
The New Year brings renewal, I know, and yet 
The same old tears still flow from the same old woman.

column1: 神垣はしるしの杉もなきものをいかにまがへておれるさか木ぞ
column2:
You err with your sacred tree and sacred gate. 
No beckoning cedars stand before my house.

column1: 少女子があたりと思へばさか木葉の香をなつかしみとめてこそおれ
column2:
Thinking to find you here with the holy maidens, 
I followed the scent of the leaf of the sacred tree.

column1: あかつきの別れはいつも露けきをこは世に知らぬ秋の空かな
column2:
A dawn farewell is always drenched in dew, 
But sad is the autumn sky as never before.

column1: おほかたの秋の別れもかなしきになく音なそへそ野辺の松虫
column2:
An autumn farewell needs nothing to make it sadder. 
Enough of your songs, O crickets on the moors!

column1: やしまもる国つ御神もこころあらばあかぬ別れの中をことはれ
column2:
If my lady the priestess, surveying her manifold realms. 
Has feelings for those below, let her feel for me.

column1: 国つ神空にことはる中ならばなをざりごとをまづやたださむ
column2:
If a lord of the land is watching from above. 
This pretense of sorrow will not have escaped his notice.

column1: そのかみをけふはかけじと忍ぶれど心のうちにものぞかなしき
column2:
Tue things of the past are always of the past. 
I would not think of them. Yet sad is my heart.

column1: ふりすててけふはゆくとも鈴鹿河八十瀬の浪に袖はぬれじや
column2:
You throw me off; but will they not wet your sleeves, 
The eighty waves of the river Suzuka?

column1: 鈴鹿河八十瀬のなみにぬれぬれず伊勢までたれか思ひをこせむ
column2:
And who will watch us all the way to Ise, 
To see if those eighty waves have done their work?

column1: 行く方をながめもやらむこの秋は逢坂山を霧なへだてそ
column2:
I see her on her way. Do not, O mists, 
This autumn close off the Gate of the Hill of Meeting.

column1: かげ広みたのみし松や枯れにけん下葉ちり行としの暮哉
column2:
Withered the pine whose branches gave us shelter? 
Now at the end of the year its needles fall.

column1: さえわたる池のかがみのさやけきに見なれしかげを見ぬぞかなしき
column2:
Clear as a mirror these frozen winter waters. 
The figure they once reflected is no more.

column1: 年くれて岩井の水もこほりとぢ見し人かげのあせも行かな
column2:
At the end of the year the springs are silenced by ice. 
And gone are they whom we saw among the rocks.

column1: 心から方方袖をぬらすかなあくとをしふる声につけても
column2:
They say that it is dawn, that you grow weary. 
I weep, my sorrows wrought by myself alone.

column1: 嘆きつつわがよはかくて過ぐせとや胸のあくべき時ぞともなく
column2:
You tell me that these sorrows must not cease? 
My sorrows, my love will neither have an ending.

column1: 逢ふことのかたきをけふにかぎらずはいまいく世をか嘆きつつへん
column2:
If other days must be as this has been, 
I still shall be weeping two and three lives hence.

column1: ながきよのうらみを人に残してもかつは心をあだと知らなむ
column2:
Remember that the cause is in yourself 
Of a sin which you say I must bear through lives to come.

column1: あさぢふの露のやどりに君ををきてよもの嵐ぞ静心なき
column2:
In lodgings frail as the dew upon the reeds 
I left you, and the four winds tear at me.

column1: 風ふけばまづぞみだるる色かはるあさぢが露にかかるささがに
column2:
Weak as the spider's thread upon the reeds, 
The dew-drenched reeds of autumn, I blow with the winds.

column1: かけまくはかしこけれどもその神の秋おもほゆる木綿襷かな
column2:
The gods will not wish me to speak of them, perhaps, 
But I think of sacred cords of another autumn.

column1: その神やいかがはありし木綿襷心にかけてしのぶらんゆへ
column2:
Another autumn―what can this refer to? 
A secret hoard of thoughts of sacred cords?

column1: 九重に霧やへだつる雲のうへの月をはるかに思やるかな
column2:
Ninefold mists have risen and come between us. 
I am left to imagine the moon beyond the clouds.

column1: 月影は見し夜の秋にかはらぬをへだつる霧のつらくもあるかな
column2:
The autumn moon is the autumn moon of old. 
How cruel the mists that will not let me see it.

column1: 木枯らしの吹くにつけつつ待ちしまにおぼつかなさのころもへにけり
column2:
Anxious, restless days. A gust of wind, 
And yet another, bringing no word from you.

column1: あひ見ずてしのぶるころの涙をもなべての空の時雨とや見る
column2:
Deceive yourself not into thinking them autumn showers, 
The tears I weep in hopeless longing to see you.

column1: 別にしけふはくれども見し人にゆきあふほどをいつとたのまん
column2:
We greet once more the day of the last farewell, 
And when, in what snows, may we hope for a day of meeting?

column1: ながらふるほどはうけれどゆきめぐりけふはその世にあふ心ちして
column2:
To live these months without him has been sorrow. 
But today seems to bring a return of the days of old.

column1: 月のすむ雲井をかけてしたふともこのよの闇に猶やまどはむ
column2:
My heart is with her in the moonlight above the clouds, 
And yet it stays with you in this darker world.

column1: おほふかたのうきにつけてはいとへどもいつかこの世をそむきはつべき
column2:
Though I leave behind a world I cannot endure, 
My heart remains with him, till of that world.

column1: ながめかるあまの住みかと見るからにまづしほたるる松がうら島
column2:
Briny my sleeves at the pines of Urashima 
As those of the fisherfolk who take the sea grass.

column1: ありし世のなごりだになき浦島にたち寄る浪のめづらしきかな
column2:
How strange that waves yet come to Urashima, 
When all the things of old have gone their way.

column1: それもがとけさひらけたる初花におとらぬ君がにほひをぞ見る
column2:
I might have met the first lily of spring,he says.
I look upon a flower no less pleasing.

column1: 時ならでけさ咲花は夏の雨にしほれにけらしにほふほどなく
column2:
The plant of which you speak bloomed very briefly. 
It opened at dawn to wilt in the summer rains,

column1: おち返りえぞ忍ばれぬほととぎすほの語らひし宿の垣根に
column2:
Back at the fence where once it sang so briefly, 
The cuckoo is impelled to sing again.

column1: ほととぎす言問ふ声はそれなれどあなおぼつかなさみだれの空
column2:
It seems to be a cuckoo we knew long ago. 
But alas, under rainy skies we cannot be sure.

column1: 橘の香をなつかしみほととぎす花散る里をたづねてぞとふ
column2:
It catches the scent of memory, and favors 
The village where the orange blossoms fall.

column1: 人目なく荒れたる宿はたちばなの花こそ軒のつまとなりけれ
column2:
The orange blossoms at the eaves have brought you 
To a dwelling quite forgotten by the world.

column1: 鳥辺山もえし煙もまがふやとあまの塩焼くうらみにぞ行く
column2:
There on the shore, the salt burners' fires await me. 
Will their smoke be as the smoke over Toribe Moor?

column1: なき人の別れやいとど隔たらむ煙となりし雲井ならでは
column2:
Farther retreats the day when we bade her goodbye, 
For now you depart the skies that received the smoke.

column1: 身はかくてさすらへぬとも君があたり去らぬ鏡の影は離れじ
column2:
I now must go into exile In this mirror 
An image of me will yet remain beside you.

column1: 別れても影だにとまるものならば鏡を見てもなぐさめてまし
column2:
If when we part an image yet remains, 
Then will I find some comfort in my sorrow.

column1: 月影の宿れる袖はせばくともとめても見ばやあかぬ光を
column2:
Narrow these sleeves, now lodging for the moonlight. 
Would they might keep a light which I do not tire of.

column1: 行きめぐりつゐにすむべき月影のしばし雲らむ空なながめそ
column2:
The moon will shine upon this house once more. 
Do not look at the clouds which now conceal it:

column1: あふ瀬なきなみだの河に沈みしや流るるみおのはじめなりけむ
column2:
Snagged upon the shoals of this river of tears, 
I cannot see you. Deeper waters await me.

column1: なみだがは浮かぶみなはも消えぬべし流れてのちの瀬をも待たずて
column2:
The foam on the river of tears will disappear 
Short of the shoals of meeting that wait downstream.

column1: 見しはなくあるはかなしき世の果てを背きしかひもなくなくぞ経る
column2:
The one whom I served is gone, the other must go. 
Farewell to the world was no farewell to its sorrows.

column1: 別れしにかなしき事は尽きにしをまたぞこの世のうさはまされる
column2:
The worst of grief for him should long have passed. 
And now I must leave the world where dwells the child.

column1: ひき連れて葵かざししそのかみを思へばつらし賀茂の瑞垣
column2:
There was heartvine in our caps. I led your horse. 
And now at this jeweled fence I berate the gods.

column1: うき世をばいまぞ別るるとどまらむ名をばただすの神にまかせて
column2:
I leave this world of gloom. I leave my name 
To the offices of the god who rectifies.

column1: なきかげやいかが見るらむよそへつつながむる月も雲がくれぬる
column2:
And how does he look upon me? I raise my eyes. 
And the moon now vanishes behind the clouds.

column1: いつかまた春のみやこの花を見ん時うしなへる山がつにして
column2:
When shall I, a ragged, rustic outcast, 
See again the blossoms of the city?

column1: 咲きてとく散るはうけれどゆく春は花のみやこを立ち帰り見よ
column2:
Quickly the blossoms fall. Though spring departs, 
You will come again. I know, to a city of flowers.

column1: 生ける世の別れを知らで契りつつ命を人にかぎりけるかな
column2:
At least for this life we might make our vows, we thought. 
And so we vowed that nothing would ever part us.

column1: おしからぬ命にかへて目の前の別れをしばしとどめてしかな
column2:
I would give a life for which I have no regrets 
If it might postpone for a little the time of parting.

column1: 唐国に名を残しける人よりもゆくゑしられぬ家居をやせむ
column2:
More remote I fear, my place of exile 
Than storied ones in lands beyond the seas.

column1: ふるさとを峰の霞はへだつれどながむる空はおなじ雲井か
column2:
Mountain mists cut off that ancient village. 
Is the sky I see the sky that shelters it?

column1: 松島のあまの苫屋もいかならむ須磨の浦人しほたるるころ
column2:
Briny our sleeves on the Suma strand; and yours 
In the fisher cots of thatch at Matsushima?

column1: こりずまの浦のみるめのゆかしきを塩焼くあまやいかが思はん
column2:
At Suma unchastened, one longs for the deep-lying sea pine. 
And she, the fisher lady burning salt?

column1: しほたるることをやくにて松島に年ふるあまもなげきをぞつむ
column2:
The nun of Matsushima burns the brine 
And fuels the fires with the logs of her lamenting,

column1: 浦にたくあまたにつつむこひなればくゆる煙よ行く方ぞなき
column2:
The fisherwife burns salt and hides her fires 
And strangles, for the smoke has no escape.

column1: 浦人のしほくむ袖にくらべみよ波路へだつる夜のころもを
column2:
Taking brine on that strand, let him compare 
His dripping sleeves with these night sleeves of mine.

column1: うきめ刈る伊勢をの海人を思ひやれ藻塩たるてふ須磨の浦にて
column2:
Imagine, at Suma of the dripping brine, 
The woman of Ise, gathering briny sea grass.

column1: 伊勢島や潮干の潟にあさりてもいふかひなきは我身なりけり
column2:
The tide recedes along the coast of Ise. 
No hope, no promise in the empty shells.

column1: 伊勢人の浪のうへこぐ小舟にもうきめは刈らで乗らましものを
column2:
With the lady of Ise I might have ridden small boats 
That row the waves, and avoided dark sea tangles.

column1: 海人がつむなげきのなかにしほたれていつまで須磨の浦にながめむ
column2:
How long, dripping brine on driftwood logs, 
On logs of lament, must I gaze at this Suma coast?

column1: 荒れまさる軒のしのぶをながめつつしげくも露のかかる袖かな
column2:
Ferns of remembrance weigh cur eaves ever more, 
And heavily falls the dew upon our sleeves.

column1: 恋わびてなく音にまがふ浦波は思ふかたより風や吹くらん
column2:
The waves on the strand, like moans of helpless longing. 
The winds―like messengers from those who grieve?

column1: 初雁は恋しき人のつらなれや旅の空とぶ声のかなしき
column2:
Might they be companions of those I long for? 
Their cries ring sadly through the sky of their journey.

column1: かきつらねむかしのことぞ思ほゆる雁はその世の友ならねども
column2:
I know not why they bring these thoughts of old, 
These wandering geese. They were not then my comrades.

column1: こころから常世を捨ててなく雁をくものよそにも思ひけるかな
column2:
No colleagues of mine, these geese beyond the clouds. 
They chose to leave their homes, and I did not.

column1: 常世いでて旅の空なる雁がねもつらにをくれぬほどぞなぐさむ
column2:
Sad are their cries as they wing their way from home. 
They still find solace, for they still have comrades.

column1: 見るほどぞしばしなぐさむめぐりあはん月のみやこははるかなれども
column2:
So long as I look upon it I find comfort, 
The moon which comes again to the distant city.

column1: うしとのみひとへにものは思ほえでひだりみぎにもぬるる袖かな
column2:
Not bitter thoughts alone does this singlet bring. 
Its sleeves are damp with tears of affection too.

column1: 琴の音にひきとめらるる綱手縄たゆたう心君しるらめや
column2:
Now taut, now slack, like my unruly heart, 
The tow rope is suddenly still at the sound of a koto.

column1: 心ありてひきての綱のたゆたはばうち過ぎましや須磨のうら浪
column2:
Why, if indeed your heart is like the tow rope, 
Unheeding must you pass this strand of Suma?

column1: 山がつのいほりに焚けるしばしばもこと問ひ来なん恋ふるさと人
column2:
Over and over the rural ones light fires. 
Not so unflagging the urban ones with their visits.

column1: いづかたの雲路に我もまよひなむ月の見るらむこともはづかし
column2:
All aimless is my journey through the clouds. 
It shames me that the unswerving moon should see me.

column1: 友千鳥もろ声に鳴くあか月はひとり寝さめの床もたのもし
column2:
.Cries of plovers in the dawn bring comfort 
To one who awakens in a lonely bed.

column1: いつとなく大宮人の恋しきに桜かざししけふを来にけり
column2:
Fond thoughts I have of the noble ones on high, 
And the day of the flowered caps has come again.

column1: ふるさとをいづれの春か行きて見んうらやましきは帰るかりがね
column2:
In what spring tide will I see again my old village? 
I envy the geese, returning whence they came

column1: あかなくにかりの常世を立ち別れ花のみやこに道やまどはむ
column2:
Sad are the geese to leave their winter's lodging. 
Dark my way of return to the flowery city.

column1: 雲ちかく飛びかふ鶴もそらに見よ我は春日のくもりなき身ぞ
column2:
Look down upon me, cranes who skim the clouds, 
And see me unsullied as this cloudless day.

column1: たづかなき雲井にひとりねをぞ泣くつばさ並べし友を恋つつ
column2:
Lonely the voice of the crane among the clouds. 
Gone the comrade that once flew at its side.

column1: 知らざりし大海の原に流れきてひとかたにやはものはかなしき
column2:
Cast away to drift on an alien vastness, 
I grieve for more than a doll cast out to sea.

column1: やをよろづ神もあはれと思ふらむをかせる罪のそれとなければ
column2:
You eight hundred myriad gods must surely help me, 
For well you know that blameless I stand before you.

column1: 浦風やいかに吹らむ思ひやる袖うち濡らし波間なきころ
column2:
What do they work, the sea winds down at Suma? 
At home, my sleeves are assaulted by wave after wave.

column1: 海にます神のたすけにかからずは潮のやをあひにさすらへなまし
column2:
Without the staying hand of the king of the sea 
The roar of the eight hundred waves would have taken us under.

column1: はるかにも思ひやるかな知らざりし浦よりをちに浦づたひして
column2:
Yet farther away, upon the beach at Akashi, 
My thoughts of a distant city, and of you.

column1: あはと見る淡路の島のあはれさへ残るくまなく澄める夜の月
column2:
Awaji in the moonlight, like distant foam: 
From these cloudly sovereign heights it seems so near.

column1: ひとり寝は君も知りぬやつれづれと思ひあかしのうらさびしさを
column2:
Do you too know the sadness of the nights 
On the shore of Akashi with only thoughts for companions?

column1: 旅ごろもうらがなしさにあかしかね草の枕は夢もむすばず
column2:
The traveler passes fretful nights at Akashi. 
The grass which he reaps for his pillow reaps no dreams.

column1: をちこちも知らぬ雲居にながめわびかすめし宿の木ずゑをぞとふ
column2:
Do I catch, as I gaze into unresponsive skies, 
A glimpse of a grove of which I have had certain tidings?

column1: ながむらんおなじ雲居をながむるは思ひもおなじ思ひなるらむ
column2:
She gazes into the skies into which you gaze. 
May they bring your thoughts and hers into some accord.

column1: いぶせくも心にものをなやむかなやよやいかにと問ふ人もなみ
column2:
Unwillingly reticent about my sorrows 
I still must be―for no one makes inquiry.

column1: 思ふらん心のほどややよいかにまだ見ぬ人の聞きかなやまむ
column2:
Unwillingly reticent―how can it be so? 
How can you sorrow for someone you have not met?

column1: 秋の夜の月げの駒よわが恋ふる雲居をかけれ時の間も見ん
column2:
Race on through the moonlit sky. O roan-colored horse. 
And let me be briefly with her for whom I long.

column1: むつごとを語りあはせむ人もがなうき世の夢もなかばさむやと
column2:
Would there were someone with whom I might share my thoughts 
And so dispel some part of these sad dreams.

column1: 明けぬ夜にやがてまどへる心にはいづれを夢とわきて語らむ
column2:
You speak to one for whom the night has no end. 
How can she tell the dreaming from the waking?

column1: しほしほとまづぞ泣かるるかりそめのみるめは海人のすさびなれども
column2:
It was but the fisherman's brush with the salty sea pine 
Followed by a tide of tears of longing.

column1: うらなくも思ひけるかな契りしを松より波はこえじ物ぞと
column2:
Naive of me, perhaps; yet we did make our vows. 
And now see the waves that wash the Mountain of Waiting!

column1: このたびは立ち別るとも藻塩焼くけぶりはおなじ方になびかむ
column2:
Even though we now must part for a time, 
The smoke from these briny fires will follow me.

column1: かきつめて海人のたく藻の思ひにもいまはかひなきうらみだにせじ
column2:
Smoldering thoughts like the sea grass burned on these shores. 
And what good now to ask for anything more?

column1: 猶ざりに頼めをくめるひとことを尽きせぬ音にやかけてしのばん
column2:
One heedless word, one koto, to set me at rest. 
In the sound of it the sound of my weeping, forever.

column1: あふまでのかたみに契る中の緒の調べはことにかはらざらなむ
column2:
Do not change the middle string* of this koto, 
Unchanging I shall be till we meet again.

column1: うち捨てて立つもかなしき浦波のなごりいかにと思ひやるかな
column2:
Sad the retreating waves at leaving this shore. 
Sad I am for you, remaining after.

column1: 年経つる苫屋も荒れてうき波のかへるかたにや身をたぐへまし
column2:
You leave, my reed-roofed hut will fall to ruin. 
Would that I might go out with these waves.

column1: 寄る波にたちかさねたる旅衣しほどけしとや人のいとはむ
column2:
I made it for you, but the surging brine has wet it. 
And might you find it unpleasant and cast it off?

column1: かたみにぞかふべかりけるあふことの日かず隔てん中のころもを
column2:
Take it. this middle robe, let it be the symbol 
Of days uncounted but few between now and then.

column1: 世をうみにここらしほじむ身と成て猶この岸をえこそ離れね
column2:
Though weary of life, seasoned by salty winds, 
I am not able to leave this shore behind,

column1: 宮こ出でし春の嘆きにおとらめや年ふる浦をわかれぬる秋
column2:
I wept upon leaving the city in the spring. 
I weep in the autumn on leaving this home by the sea.

column1: わたつ海にしなへうらぶれ蛭の子の脚立たざりし年は経にけり
column2:
Cast out upon the sea. I passed the years 
As useless as the leech child of the gods.

column1: 宮柱めぐりあひける時しあれば別れし春のうらみのこすな
column2:
The leech child's parents met beyond the pillar. 
We meet again to forget the spring of parting.

column1: 嘆きつつあかしの浦に朝露のたつやと人を思ひやるかな
column2:
I wonder, do the morning mists yet rise, 
There at Akashi of the lonely nights?

column1: 須磨の浦に心をよせし舟人のやがて朽たせる袖をみせばや
column2:
There once came tidings from a boat at Suma, 
From one who now might show You sodden sleeves.

column1: 帰てはかことやせまし寄せたりしなごりに袖の干がたかりしを
column2:
It is I, not you, from whom the complaints should come. 
My sleeves have refused to dry since last you wrote.

column1: かねてより隔てぬ中ならはねど別れはおしき物にぞありける
column2:
I have not, it is true, been so fortunate as to know you, 
But sad it is to end the briefest friendship.

column1: うちつけの別れをおしむかごとにて思はむ方にしたひやはせぬ
column2:
I do not trust regrets at so quick a farewell. 
The truth has to do with someone you wish to visit.

column1: いつしかも袖うちかけむおとめ子が世をへてなづる岩の生い先
column2:
One day this sleeve of mine shall be her shelter 
Whose years shall be as the years of the angel's rock.

column1: ひとりしてなづるは袖のほどなきに覆ふばかりの陰をしぞまつ
column2:
These sleeves are much too narrow to offer protection. 
The blossom awaits those all-encompassing ones.

column1: 思ふどちなびく方にはあらずともわれぞ煙に先立ちなまし
column2:
I think I shall be the first to rise as smoke, 
And it may not go the direction of that other.

column1: たれにより世をうみ山に行めぐりたえぬ涙に浮き沈む身ぞ
column2:
For whom, in mountains, upon unfriendly seas, 
Has the flow of my tears been such as to sweep me under?

column1: 海松や時ぞともなき陰にゐてなにのあやめもいかにわくらむ
column2:
The sea grass, hidden among the rocks, unchanging, 
Competes this day for attention with the iris.

column1: 数ならぬみ島がくれに鳴く鶴をけふもいかにと問ふ人ぞなき
column2:
The crane is lost on an insignificant isle. 
Not even today do you come to seek it out.

column1: 水鶏だにおどろかさずはいかにして荒れたる宿に月を入れまし
column2:
Did not this bird come knocking at my door, 
What pretext would I find to admit the moon?

column1: をしなべて叩く水鶏におどろかばうはの空なる月もこそ入れ
column2:
You respond to the call of every water rail? 
You must find yourself admitting peculiar moons.

column1: 住吉の松こそものはかなしけれ神世のことをかけて思へば
column2:
These pines of Sumiyoshi make me think 
Of days when we were neighbors to this god.

column1: あらかりし波のまよひに住吉の神をばかけて忘れやはする
column2:
Remembering those fearful winds and waves, 
Am I to forget the god of Sumiyoshi?

column1: みをつくし恋ふるしるしにここまでもめぐりあひけるえには深しな
column2:
Firm the bond that brings us to Naniwa, 
Whose channel buoys invite me to throw myself in.

column1: 数ならでなにはのこともかひなきになどみをつくし思ひそめけむ
column2:
A lowly one whose place is not to demand, 
To what purpose, at Naniwa, should I cast myself in?

column1: 露けさのむかしに似たる旅ごろも田蓑の島の名にはかくれず
column2:
My sleeves are wet as when I wandered these shores. 
The Isle of the Raincoat does not fend off the dews.

column1: 降り乱れひまなき空に亡き人の天翔るらむ宿ぞかなしき
column2:
From skies of wild, unceasing snow and sleet 
Her spirit watches over a house of sorrow.

column1: 消えがてにふるぞかなしきかきくらしわが身それとも思ほえぬ世に
column2:
I wish to go, but, blind with tears, am helpless 
As snows which were not asked where they would fall.

column1: たゆまじき筋を頼みし玉かづら思ひのほかにかけはなれぬる
column2:
I had counted upon them not to slacken or give, 
These jeweled strands―and far off now they are borne.

column1: 玉かづら絶えてもやまじゆく道の手向の神もかけて誓はむ
column2:
The jeweled strands may snap, but I swear by the gods, 
The gods of the road, that I will not cast them off.

column1: 亡き人を恋ふる袂のひまなきに荒れたる軒のしづくさへ添ふ
column2:
My sleeves still wet from tears for him who died 
Are wetter yet from rain through ruined eaves.

column1: たづねともわれこそとはめ道もなく深きのもとの心を
column2:
Myself will I break a path through towering weeds 
And ask: does a constant spirit dwell within?

column1: 藤浪のうち過ぎがたく見えつるはまつこそ宿のしるしなりけれ
column2:
I obey the waving summons of wisteria 
Because it flows, at your gate, from the waiting tree.

column1: 年を経てまつしるしなきわが宿を花のたよりにすぎぬばかりか
column2:
I have waited and waited, to no avail, it seems. 
Wisteria, not the waiting pine, has brought you.

column1: 行くと来とせきとめがたき涙をや絶えぬ清水と人は見るらむ
column2:
It flowed as I went, it flows as I return, 
The steady crystal spring at the barrier rise.

column1: わくらばに行きあふ道をたのみしも猶かひなしやしほならぬ海
column2:
By chance we met, beside the gate of meeting. 
A pity its fresh waters should be so sterile.

column1: あふさかの関やいかなる関なればしげきなげきの中をわくらん
column2:
The gate of meeting, atop the barrier rise, 
Is shaded by impassable wailing groves.

column1: わかれ路に添へし小をかことにてはるけき中と神やいさめし
column2:
I gave you combs and sent you far away. 
The god now sends me far away from you?

column1: 別るとてはるかにいひしひとこともかへりてものはいまぞかなしき
column2:
Long ago, one word you said: Away! 
Sorry now am I that I paid no heed.

column1: ひとりゐて嘆きしよりは海人のすむかたをかくてぞ見るべかりける
column2:
Better to see these strands where the fishermen dwell 
Than far away to weep, all, all alone.

column1: うきめ見しそのおりよりもけふはまた過ぎにしかたにかへる涙か
column2:
Now more than in those painful days I weep 
As tracings of them bring them back to me.

column1: 伊勢の海の深き心をたどらずてふりにしあとと波や消つべき
column2:
Shall we forget how deep is the sea of Ise 
Because the waves have washed away old tracks?

column1: 雲の上に思ひのぼれるこころにはちいろの底もはるかにぞ見る
column2:
To this Josammi, high above august clouds, 
The thousand-fathomed sea seems very shallow.

column1: みるめこそうらふりぬらめ年へにし伊勢をの海人の名をや沈めむ
column2:
At first the strands of sea grass may seem old, 
But the fisherfolk of Ise are with us yet.

column1: 身こそかくしめのほかなれそのかみの心のうちを忘れしもせず
column2:
Though now I dwell beyond the sacred confines. 
My heart is there committing you to the gods.

column1: しめのうちはむかしにあらぬここちして神代の事もいまぞ恋しき
column2:
Within these sacred precincts all has changed. 
Fondly I think of the days when I served the gods.

column1: ゆくさきをはるかに祈るわかれ路にたえぬは老いの涙なりけり
column2:
The old weep easily. and I am weeping 
As I pray that for her the happy years stretch on.

column1: もろともにみやこは出できこのたびやひとり野中のみちにまどはん
column2:
Together we left the city. Alone I return, 
To wander lost over hill and over moor?

column1: いきてまたあひ見むことをいつとてか限りもしらぬ世をばたのまむ
column2:
When do you say that we shall meet again, 
Trusting a life that is not ours to trust?

column1: かの岸に心よりにしあま舟のそむきしかたにこぎかへる哉
column2:
I want to be a fisherwife upon 
A far, clean shore, and now my boat turns back.

column1: いくかへりゆきかふ秋をすぐしつつうき木にのりてわれかへるらん
column2:
How many autumns now upon this strand? 
So many, why should this flotsam now return?

column1: 身をかへてひとりかへれる山ざとに聞きしにたる松風ぞふく
column2:
I have returned alone, a nun, to a mountain village, 
And hear the wind in the pines of long ago.

column1: ふる里に見しよのともをこひわびてさえづることをたれかわくらん
column2:
I long for those who know the country sounds, 
And listen to my koto, and understand.

column1: すみなれし人はかへりてたどれども清水は宿のあるじ顔なる
column2:
The mistress, long gone, is lost upon her return 
To find that the brook has quite usurped her claims.

column1: いさらゐははやくにことも忘れじをもとのあるじや面がはりせる
column2:
Clean waters, bringing back the distant past 
To one who comes to them in somber habit.

column1: 契りしに変はらぬことの調べにて絶えぬ心のほどは知りきや
column2:
Unchanged it is when now we meet again. 
And do you not see changelessness in me?

column1: 変はらじと契りしことをたのみにて松のひびきに音をそへしかな
column2:
Your promise not to change was my companion. 
I added my sighs to those of the wind in the pines.

column1: 月のそむ川のをちなる里なればかつらのかげはのどけかるらむ
column2:
Cleaner, more stately the progress of the moon 
Through regions beyond the river Katsura.

column1: ひさかたのひかり近き名のみしてあさゆふ霧も晴れぬ山里
column2:
It Is not true to its name, this Katsura. 
There is not moon enough to dispel the mists.

column1: めぐり来て手にとるばかりさやけきや淡路の島のあはと見し月
column2:
So near and clear tonight, is it the moon 
Of far Awaji? We both have come back.

column1: うき雲にしばしまがひし月かげのすみはつるよぞのどけかるべき
column2:
All should now be peace. Then lost in clouds 
The moon sends forth again its radiance.

column1: 雲のうへのすみかをすててよはの月いづれの谷にかげ隠しけむ
column2:
The midnight moon should still be in the heavens. 
Gone is its radiance―-hidden in what valley?

column1: 雪ふかみ深山のみちははれずとも猶ふみかよへあとたえずして
column2:
These mountain paths will be closed by snow and clouds. 
Do not, I pray you, let your tracks be lost.

column1: 雪まなき吉野の山をたづねても心のかよふあとたえめやは
column2:
And were you to move to deepest Yoshino, 
I still would find you, through unceasing snow.

column1: 末とをき二葉の松にひきわかれいつか木たかきかげを見るべき
column2:
It is taken away, the seedling pine, so young. 
When shall I see it grandly shading the earth?

column1: 生ひそめし根もふかければ武隈の松に小松の千代をならべん
column2:
A seedling, yes, but with the roots to give 
The thousand years of the pines of Takekuma.

column1: 舟とむるをちかた人のなくはこそあす帰り来むせなと待ちみめ
column2:
We shall see if you are back tomorrow, 
If no one there essays to take your boat.

column1: 行てみてあすもさね来む中中にをちかた人は心をくとも
column2:
I go but for a while, and shall return 
Though she may wish I had not come at all.

column1: 入日さす峰のたなびく薄曇はもの思ふ袖に色やまがへる
column2:
A rack of cloud across the light of evening 
As if they too, these hills, wore mourning weeds.

column1: 君もさはあはれをかはせ人しれずわが身にしむる秋の夕風
column2:
Then we two feel alike. You know my secret: 
For me it is the autumn winds that pierce.

column1: いざりせし影忘られぬかがり火は身のうき舟やしたひきにけん
column2:
The torches bobbing with the fisher boats 
Upon those waves have Followed me to Oi.

column1: あさからぬ下の思ひをしらねばや猶かがり火の影はさはげる
column2:
Only one who does not know deep waters 
Can still be bobbing, dancing on those waves.

column1: 人知れず神のゆるしを待ちしまにここらつれなき世を過ぐすかな
column2:
One does indeed wait long and cheerless months 
In hopes the gods will someday give their blessing.

column1: なべて世のあはればかりを問ふからに誓ひしことと神やいさめむ
column2:
The gods will tell me I have broken my vows 
For having had the briefest talk with you.

column1: 見しおりの露忘られぬあさがほの花のさかりはすぎやしぬらん
column2:
I do not forget the morning glory I saw. 
Will the years, I wonder, have taken it past its bloom?

column1: 秋はてて霧のまがきにむすぼほれあるかなきかにうつるあさがほ
column2:
The morning glory, wholly changed by autumn, 
Is lost in the tangle of the dew-drenched hedge.

column1: いつのまによもぎがもととむすぼほれ雪ふる里と荒れし垣根ぞ
column2:
And when did wormwood overwhelm this gate, 
This hedge, now under snow, so go to ruin?

column1: 年ふれどこの契こそわすられね親の親とかいひし一言
column2:
I do not forget that bond, though years have passed, 
For did you not choose to call me Mother's mother?

column1: 身をかへて後も待ちみよこの世にて親を忘るるためしありやと
column2:
Suppose we wait for another world to tell us 
Of instances of a child's forgetting a parent.

column1: つれなきをむかしにこりぬ心こそ人のつらきにそへてつらけれ
column2:
Long years of coldness have not chastened me, 
And now I add resentment to resentment.

column1: あらためてなにかは見えむ人のうへにかかりと聞きし心がはりを
column2:
I could not change if I wished at this late date. 
I know that others do, but I cannot.

column1: こほりとぢ石間の水はゆきなやみ空すむ月のかげぞながるる
column2:
The water is stilled among the frozen rocks. 
A clear moon moves into the western sky.

column1: かきつめてむかし恋しき雪もよにあはれをそふるをしのうきねか
column2:
A night of drifting snow and memories 
Is broken by another note of sadness.

column1: とけてねぬ寝覚めさびしき冬の夜にむすぼほれつる夢のみじかさ
column2:
A winter's night, I awaken from troubled sleep. 
And what a brief and fleeting dream it was!

column1: なき人をしたふ心にまかせてもかげ見ぬ三つ瀬にやまどはむ
column2:
I fear, in my longing, to go in search of her 
And find not her shade on the banks of the River of Death.

column1: かけきやは川瀬の波もたちかへり君がみそぎのふぢのやつれを
column2:
I did not think that when the waters returned 
It would be to take away the weeds of mourning.

column1: ふぢごろも着しはきのふと思ふまにけふはみそぎの瀬にかはる世を
column2:
How quick the change. Deep mourning yesterday, 
Today the shallow waters of lustration.

column1: さ夜中に友呼びわたる雁にうたて吹きそふ荻のうは風
column2:
The midnight call to its fellows in the clouds 
Comes in upon the wind that rustles the reeds,

column1: くれなゐの涙にふかき袖の色をあさみどりにや言ひしほるべき
column2:
These sleeves are crimson, dyed with tears of blood. 
How can she say that they are lowly blue?

column1: いろいろに身のうきほどの知らるるはいかに染めける中のころもぞ
column2:
My life is dyed with sorrows of several hues. 
Pray tell me which is the hue of the part we share.

column1: 霜氷うたてむすべる明け暮れの空かきくらしふる涙かな
column2:
It is a world made grim by frost and ice, 
And now come tears to darken darkened skies.

column1: あめにますとよをかひめの宮人もわが心ざすしめを忘るな
column2:
The lady who serves Toyooka in the heavens 
Is not to forget that someone thinks of her here.

column1: おとめ子も神さびぬらしあまつ袖ふるき世の友よはひ経ぬれば
column2:
What will the years have done to the maiden, when he 
Who saw her heavenly sleeves is so much older?

column1: かけていえばけふのこととぞ思ふゆる日影の霜の袖にとけしも
column2:
Garlands in my hair, warm sun to melt the frost, 
So very long ago. It seems like yesterday.

column1: 日影にもしるかりけめや小女子が天の羽袖にかけし心は
column2:
Were you aware of it as you danced in the sunlight, 
The heart that was pinned upon the heavenly sleeves?

column1: うぐひすのさえづる声はむかしにてむつれし花のかげぞかはれる
column2:
The warblers are today as long ago, 
But we in the shade of the blossoms are utterly changed.

column1: 九重をかすみ隔てつるすみかにも春とつげくる鶯の声
column2:
Though kept by mists from the ninefold-garlanded court. 
I yet have warblers to tell me spring has come.

column1: いにしへを吹き伝へたる笛竹にさえづる鳥の音さへ変わらぬ
column2:
The tone of the flute is as it always has been, 
Nor do I detect a change in the song of the warbler.

column1: 鶯のむかしを恋ひてさえづるは木伝ふ花の色やあせたる
column2:
The warbler laments as it flies from tree to tree―
For blossoms whose hue is paler than once it was?

column1: 心から春まつそのはわがやどの紅葉を風のつてにだに見よ
column2:
Your garden quietly awaits the spring. 
Permit the winds to bring a touch of autumn.

column1: 風に散る紅葉はかろし春の色を岩根の松にかけてこそ見め
column2:
Fleeting, your leaves that scatter in the wind. 
The pine at the cliffs is forever green with the spring.

column1: 舟人もたれを恋ふとか大島のうらがなしげに声の聞こゆる
column2:
To whom might it be that the thoughts of these sailors turn, 
Sadly singing off the Oshima strand?

column1: 来しかたも行くゑも知らぬ沖に出でてあはれいづくに君を恋ふらん
column2:
To whom might it be that the thoughts of these sailors turn, 
Sadly singing off the Oshima strand?

column1: 君にもし心たがはば松浦なる鏡の神をかけて誓はむ
column2:
I vow to the Mirror God of Matsura: 
If I break it he can do what he wants with me.

column1: 年を経て祈る心のたがひなば鏡の神をつらしとや見む
column2:
It will be for us to reproach the Mirror God 
If our prayers of so many years remain unanswered.

column1: 浮嶋を漕ぎ離れても行く方やいづくとまりと知らずもあるかな
column2:
Shores of trial, now gloomy Ukishima. 
On we sail. Where next will be our lodging?

column1: 行く先も見えぬ浪路に舟出して風にまかする身こそうきたれ
column2:
We sail vast seas and know not where we go 
Floating ones, abandoned to the winds.

column1: うきことに胸のみさはぐひびきにはひびきの灘もさはらざりけり
column2:
The echoes of Echo Bay are slight and empty 
Beside the tumult I hear within myself.

column1: 二もとの杉のたちどを尋ねずはふる河のべに君を見ましや
column2:
Had I not come to the place of cedars twain,
How should I have met you here beside the old river?

column1: 初瀬河はやくの事は知らねどもけふのあふ瀬に身さへながれぬ
column2:
I know little, I fear, about the swift old river, 
But I know the flow of tears of happiness.

column1: 知らずとも尋ねて知らむ三島江に生ふる三稜の筋は絶えじを
column2:
You may not know, but presently you will, 
Where leads the line of rushes at Mishimae.

column1: 数ならぬ三稜やなにの筋なればうきにしもかく根をとどめけむ
column2:
You speak of lines and rushes―and by what line 
Has this poor rush taken root in this sad world?

column1: 恋ひわたる身はそれなれど玉かづらいかなる筋を尋ね来つらむ
column2:
With unabated longing I sought the other. 
What lines have drawn me to the jeweled chaplet?

column1: きてみればうらみられけり唐衣かへしやりてん袖をぬらして
column2:
Tearfully I don this Chinese robe. 
And having dampened its sleeves, I now return it.

column1: 返さむといふにつけても片敷の夜の衣を思ひこそやれ
column2:
'Return,' you say―-ah, 'turn,' I see you mean, 
Your Chinese robe, prepared for lonely slumber.

column1: うす氷とけぬる池の鏡には世にくもりなき影ぞならべる
column2:
The mirror of this lake, now freed from ice. 
Offers an image of utter peace and calm.

column1: くもりなき池の鏡によろづ代をすむべき影ぞしるく見えける
column2:
Upon the cloudless mirror of this lake, 
Clear is the image, for ten thousand years.

column1: 年月をまつにひかれてふる人にけふ鶯の初音きかせよ
column2:
The old one's gaze rests long on the seedling pine, 
Waiting to hear the song of the first warbler,

column1: ひきわかれ年は経れども鶯の巣立ちし松の根を忘れめや
column2:
The warbler left its nest long years ago, 
But cannot forget the roots of the waiting pine.

column1: めづらしや花のねぐらに木づたひて谷のふる巣をとへる鶯
column2:
Such happiness! The warbler among the blossoms 
Calls across the glen to its old nest.

column1: ふる里の春のこずゑに尋きて世のつねならぬ花を見るかな
column2:
I stop to look at the groves of my old village, 
And the blossom I see reminds me of a safflower.

column1: 風吹けば波の花さへ色見えてこや名に立てる山吹の崎
column2:
The breezes blow, the wave flowers brightly blossom. 
Will it be the Cape of Yamabuki?

column1: 春の池や井手の川瀬にかよふらん岸の山吹そこもにほへり
column2:
Is this the lake where flows the River of Ide, † 
That yamabuki should plunge into its depths?

column1: 亀の上の山もたづねじ舟のうちに老いせぬ名をばこゝに残さむ
column2:
There is no need to visit Turtle Mountain. ‡ 
'Ageless' shall be the name of our pleasure boats.

column1: 春の日のうらゝにさしてゆく舟はさほのしづくも花ぞ散りける
column2:
Our boats row out into the bright spring sun, 
And water drops from the oars like scattering petals.

column1: むらさきのゆへに心をしめたればふちに身投げん名やはおしけき
column2:
Lavender holds me and puts me in mind of things. 
I mean, let them say what they will, to throw myself in.

column1: ふちに身を投げつべしやとこの春は花のあたりを立ち去らで見よ
column2:
Please hold yourself In abeyance beneath these flowers, 
To judge if the plunge would have the proper effect.

column1: 花園の胡蝶をさへや下草に秋まつ虫はうとく見るらむ
column2:
Low in your grasses the cricket awaits the autumn 
And views with scorn these silly butterflies.

column1: こてふにも誘はれなまし心ありて八重山吹を隔てざりせば
column2:
I weep in my longing to follow your butterflies. 
You put up fences of yamabuki between us.

column1: 思ふとも君は知らじなわきかへり岩漏る水に色し見えねば
column2:
You cannot know how deep my feelings are. 
Their colors are hidden, like waters among the rocks.

column1: ませのうちに根ふかくうへし竹の子のをのが世ゝにや生ひわかるべき
column2:
The bamboo so firmly rooted within our hedges 
Will send out distant shoots to please its convenience?

column1: いまさらにいかならむ世か若竹の生いはじめけむ根をばたづねん
column2:
Why should the young bamboo at this late date 
Go forth in search of roots it has left behind,

column1: たちばなのかほりし袖によそふればかはれる身とも思ほえぬかな
column2:
Scented by orange blossoms long ago, 
The sleeve she wore is surely the sleeve you wear.

column1: 袖の香をよそふるからにたちばなのみさへはかなくなりもこそすれ
column2:
The sleeve bears the scent of that blossom long ago. 
Then might not the fruit as quickly vanish away?

column1: うちとけてねも見ぬものを若草のことあり顔に結ぼほるらむ
column2:
Although I scarcely saw the tender grasses, 
They look as if I had tied them all in knots.

column1: なく声もきこえぬ虫の思ひだに人の消つにはきゆるものかは
column2:
You put out this silent fire to no avail. 
Can you extinguish the fire in the human heart?

column1: な声はせで身をのみこがす蛍こそいふよりまさるおもひなるらめ
column2:
The firefly but burns and makes no comment. 
Silence sometimes tells of deeper thoughts.

column1: なけふさへやひく人もなき水隠れに生ふるあやめのねのみなかれん
column2:
Even today the iris is neglected. 
Its roots, my cries, are lost among the waters.

column1: なあらはれていとゞ浅くも見ゆるかなあやめもわかずなかれけるねの
column2:
It might have flourished better in concealment, 
The iris root washed purposelessly away.

column1: その駒もすさめぬ草と名にたてるみぎはのあやめけふやひきつる
column2:
You honor the iris on the bank to which 
No pony comes to taste of withered grasses?

column1: にほどりに影をならぶる若駒はいつかあやめにひきわかるべき
column2:
This pony, like the love grebe, wants a comrade. 
Shall it forget the iris on the bank?

column1: 思ひあまりむかしのあとをたづぬれど親にそむける子ぞたぐひなき
column2:
Beside myself, I search through all the books, 
And come upon no daughter so unfilial.

column1: ふるきあとをたづぬれどげになかりけりこの世にかゝる親の心は
column2:
So too it is with me. I too have searched, 
And found no cases quite so unparental.

column1: 撫子のとこなつかしき色を見ばもとのかきねを人やたづねむ
column2:
Were he to see its gentle hues unchanging, 
Would he not come to the hedge of the wild carnation?

column1: 山がつのかきほに生ひし撫子のもとの根ざしをたれかたづねん
column2:
Who would come to seek the wild carnation 
That grew at such a rough and rustic hedge?

column1: 草若み常陸の浦のいかゞ崎いかであひ見ん田子の浦波
column2:
Cape How of the grassy pastures of Hitachi 
Says how can the waves of Farmer Beach come see you.

column1: 常陸なる駿河の海の須磨の浦に波立ち出でよ箱崎の松
column2:
You waves of the Suma coast of Suruga-
Hitachi, the pine of Hakosaki waits.

column1: 篝火にたちそふ恋のけぶりこそ世にはたえせぬほのをなりけれ
column2:
They burn, these flares and my heart, and send off smoke. 
The smoke from my heart refuses to be dispersed.

column1: 行ゑなき空に消ちてよ篝火のたよりにたぐふけぶりとならば
column2:
If from your heart and the flares the smoke is the same, 
Then one might expect it to find a place in the heavens.

column1: おほかたにおぎの葉過ぐる風のをともうき身ひとつにしむ心ちして
column2:
Even the wind that rustles the leaves of the reeds 
Is with me longer in my lonely vigil.

column1: 吹きみだる風のけしきにをみなへししほれしぬべき心ちこそすれ
column2:
The tempest blows, the maiden flower has fears 
That the time has come for it to fade and die.

column1: 下露になびかましかばをみなへしあらき風にはしほれざらまし
column2:
If it gives itself up to the dew beneath the tree, 
It need not fear, the maiden flower, the winds.

column1: 風さはぎらむ雲まがふ夕にもわするゝまなくわすられぬ君
column2:
Even on a night of raging tempests 
I did not forget the one whom I do not forget.

column1: 雪深き小塩の山にたつ雉の古き跡をもけふは尋よ
column2:
Deep in the snows of this Mount Oshio 
Are ancient pheasant tracks. Would you might see them.

column1: 小塩山みゆきつもれる松原にけふばかりなる跡やなからむ
column2:
The snows beneath the pines of Oshio 
Have never known so mighty a company.

column1: うちきらし朝ぐもりせしみ雪にはさやかに空の光やは見し
column2:
Amid deep snows upon a day of clouds 
How does one see the radiance far above?

column1: あかねさす光は空にくもらぬをなどてみ雪に目をきらしけむ
column2:
The crimson glow is there in a cloudless sky. 
Have you let yourself be blinded by the snow?

column1: ふた方にいひもてゆけば玉くしげわが身はなれぬかけごなりけり
column2:
Whatever lid the jeweled comb box bears, 
I still shall think it no one's box but mine.

column1: 我身こそ恨られけれ唐衣君がたもとになれずと思へば
column2:
How very unhappy I am, for my Chinese sleeves 
Cannot be friends with the sleeves of your Chinese robe.

column1: 唐衣又から衣からころもかへすかへすもから衣なる
column2:
A Chinese robe, a Chinese robe once more, 
And yet again a Chinese Chinese robe.

column1: うらめしや興津玉もをかづくまで磯がくれける海人の心よ
column2:
Bitter, bitter, that the fisherfolk 
So long have hidden the treasures of the sea.

column1: よるべなみかゝるなぎさにうち寄せて海人もたづねめもくづとぞ見し
column2:
The fisherfolk refusing to take them in, 
The grasses drifted ashore as best they might.

column1: おなじ野の露にやつるゝ藤袴あはれはかけよかことばかりも
column2:
Dew drenched purple trousers: I grieve as you do. 
And long for the smallest hint that you understand.

column1: たづぬるにはるけき野辺の露ならばうす紫やかことならまし
column2:
It grew, if you ask, in the dews of a distant moor. 
That purple is false which tells of anything nearer.

column1: 妹背山ふかき道をばたづねずてをだえの橋にふみまよひける
column2:
I did not know it was Sibling Mountain we climbed, 
And came to a halt on hostile Odae Bridge.

column1: まどひける道をば知らず妹背山たどたどしくぞたれもふみみし
column2:
Not knowing that you did not know, i found 
Your tracks up sibling mountain strange indeed.

column1: 数ならばいとひもせまし長月に命をかくるほどぞはかなき
column2:
Hateful the Long Month* to those who are sure of themselves. 
I hang, as if for my life, on each fleeting day.

column1: 朝日さす光を見ても玉笹の葉分けの霜を消たずもあらなむ
column2:
Warm though it be in the radiant morning sun, 
Let the jeweled bamboo not forget the frost beneath.

column1: 忘れなむと思ふも物のかなしきをいかさまにしていかさまにせむ
column2:
Difficult it is to try to forget. 
What shall I do about you, about myself?

column1: 心もて光にむかふあふひだに朝をく霜をおのれやは消つ
column2:
Not the sunflower, choosing to follow the sun, 
Forgets so soon the morning frost beneath.

column1: おりたちて汲みはみねども渡り川人の瀬とはた契らざりしを
column2:
I made no move myself to try the river, 
But I did not think to see you cross with another.

column1: みつせ川わたらぬさきにいかでなを涙のみをのあはと消えなん
column2:
I wish I might vanish as foam on a river of tears. 
Before I come to the river Mitsuse.

column1: 心さへ空にみだれし雪もよにひとり冴えつるかたしきの袖
column2:
I lie in the cold embrace of my own sleeves. 
Turmoil in the skies and in my heart.

column1: ひとりゐてこがるゝ胸のくるしきに思ひあまれるほのをとぞ見し
column2:
Alone with thoughts which are too much for her, 
She has let unquenchable embers do their work.

column1: うきことを思ひさはげばさまさまにくゆる煙ぞいとゞ立ちそふ
column2:
These dread events so fill me with rage and regret 
That I too choke from the fumes that rise within me.

column1: いまはとて宿かれぬとも馴れきつる真木の柱はわれを忘るな
column2:
And now I leave this house behind forever. 
Do not forget me, friendly cypress pillar.

column1: 馴れきとは思ひ出づともなににより立ちとまるべき真木の柱ぞ
column2:
Even if it wishes to be friends, 
We may not stay behind at this cypress pillar.

column1: 浅けれど石間の水はすみはてて宿もる君やかけはなるべき
column2:
The waters, though shallow, remain among the rocks, 
And gone is the image of one who would stay beside them.

column1: ともかくも岩間の水の結ぼほれかけとむべくも思ほえぬ世を
column2:
The water among the rocks has clouded over, 
I do not think my shadow long will linger.

column1: みやま木に羽うちかはしゐる鳥のまたなくねたき春にもあるかな
column2:
You fly off wing to wing through mountain forests, 
And in this nest of mine it is lonely spring.

column1: などてかくはひあひがたき紫を心に深く思ひそめけむ
column2:
Why should I be drawn to lavender 
So utterly remote and uncongenial?

column1: いかならん色とも知らぬ紫を心してこそ人はそめけれ
column2:
I know not the meaning of this lavender, 
Though finding in it marks of august grace.

column1: 九重にかすみへだてば梅の花たゞかばかりも匂ひこじとや
column2:
Invisible beyond the ninefold mists, 
May not the plum blossom leave its scent behind?

column1: かばかりは風にもつてよ花の枝にたちならぶべきにほひなくとも
column2:
I count not myself among the finer branches, 
Yet hope that the fragrance may float upon the breeze.

column1: かきたれてのどけき比の春雨にふるさと人をいかにしのぶや
column2:
A quiet night in spring. It rains and rains. 
Do your thoughts retum to the village you left behind?

column1: ながめする軒のしづくに袖ぬれてうたかた人をしのばざらめや
column2:
It rains and rains. My sleeves have no time to dry. 
Of forgetfulness there comes not the tiniest drop.

column1: 思はずにい手のなか道へだつとも言はでぞ恋ふる山吹の花
column2:
The yamabuki wears the hue of silence, 
So sudden was the parting at Ide road．

column1: おなじ巣にかへりしかひの見えぬかないかなる人か手ににぎるらん
column2:
I saw the duckling hatch and disappear. 
Sadly I ask who may have taken it.

column1: 巣がくれて数にもあらぬかりのこをいづ方にかはとりかくすべき
column2:
Off in a corner not counted among the nestlings, 
It was hidden by no one. It merely picked up and left.

column1: 興津ふねよるべなみ路にたゞよはばさほさしよらむとまり教へよ
column2:
If you're a little boat with nowhere to go, 
Just tell me where you're tied. I'll row out and meet you.

column1: よるべなみ風のさはがす舟人も思はぬかたに磯づたいせず
column2:
Not even a boatman driven off course by the winds 
Would wish to make for so untamed a shore.

column1: 花の香は散りにし枝にとまらねどうつらむ袖にあさくしまめや
column2:
Its blossoms fallen, the plum is of no further use. 
Let its fragrance sink into the sleeves of another.

column1: 花の枝にいとゞ心をしむるかな人のとがめん香をばつゝめど
column2:
The perfume must be hidden lest people talk, 
But I cannot take my eye from so lovely a blossom.

column1: うぐひすの声にやいとゞあくがれん心しめつる花のあたりに
column2:
The voice of the warbler lays a deeper spell 
Over one already enchanted by the blossoms.

column1: 色も香もうつるばかりにこの春は花さく宿をかれずもあらなん
column2:
Honor us by sharing our blossoms this spring 
Until you have taken on their hue and fragrance.

column1: 鴬のねぐらの枝もなびくまでなをふきとをせ夜半の笛竹
column2:
Sound your bamboo flute all through the night 
And shake the plum branch where the warbler sleeps.

column1: 心ありて風の避くめる花の木にとりあへぬまでふきやよるべき
column2:
I thought we wished to protect them from the winds, 
The blossoms you would have me blow upon madly.

column1: かすみだに月と花とをへだてずはねぐらの鳥もほころびなまし
column2:
Did not the mists intercede to dim the moonlight 
The birds on these branches might burst into joyous blossom.

column1: 花の香をえならぬ袖にうつしもてことあやまりと妹やとがめむ
column2:
If she catches a scent of blossoms upon these robes. 
My lady will charge me with having misbehaved.

column1: めづらしとふる里人もまちぞ見む花の錦を着てかへる君
column2:
I should have thought your lady might be pleased 
To have you come home all flowers and brocades.

column1: つれなさはうき世のつねになりゆくを忘れぬ人や人にことなる
column2:
This coldness takes you the usual way of the world. 
Am I the deviant, that I cannot forget you?

column1: かぎりとて忘がたきを忘るゝもこや世になびく心なるらむ
column2:
You cannot forget, and now you have forgotten. 
You are the one who goes the way of the world.

column1: わがやどの藤の色こきたそかれにたづねやはこぬ春のなごりを
column2:
Come join me in regrets for the passing of spring 
And wisteria now aglow in the evening light.

column1: 中中に折やまどはむ藤の花たそかれどきのたどたどしくは
column2:
I grope my way through the gathering shades of evening 
With no great hopes of coming upon wisteria.

column1: 紫にかことはかけむ藤の花まつよりすぎてうれたけれども
column2:
Let us blame the wisteria, of too pale a hue, 
Though the pine has let itself be overgrown.

column1: 幾かへり露けき春をすぐしきて花のひもとくをりにあふらん
column2:
Tears have obscured the blossoms these many springs, 
And now at length they open full before me.

column1: たをやめの袖にまがへる藤の花見る人からや色もまさらむ
column2:
Wisteria is like the sleeve of a maiden. 
Lovelier when someone cares for it.

column1: 浅き名をいひながしける川くちはいかゞもらしし関のあらがき
column2:
So shallow a river, flowing out to sea. 
Why did so stout a fence permit it to pass?

column1: もりにけるくきたの関を川くちの浅きにのみはおほせざらなん
column2:
Shallowness was one, but only one, 
Among the traits that helped it pass the barrier.

column1: とがむなよ忍びにしぼる手もたゆみけふあらはるゝ袖のしづくを
column2:
Do not reprove me for the dripping sleeves 
The whole world sees. I weary of wringing them dry.

column1: なにとかやけふのかざしよかつ見つゝおぼめくまでもなりにけるかな
column2:
This sprig of―what is it called?―this sprig in my cap. 
So long it has been, I cannot think of the name.

column1: かざしてもかつたどらるゝ草の名は桂をおりし人や知るらん
column2:
The scholar armed with laurel should know its name. 
He wears it, though he may not speak of it.

column1: あさみどりわか葉の菊を露にても濃きむらさきの色とかけきや
column2:
Did you suspect by so much as a mist of dew 
That the azure bloom would one day be a deep purple?

column1: ふた葉より名立たる園の菊なればあさき色わく露もなかりき
column2:
What mist of dew could possibly fail to find it, 
Though pale its hue, in so eminent a garden?

column1: なれこそは岩もるあるじ見し人のゆくゑは知るや宿の真清水
column2:
Clearest of brooks, you guard these rocks, this house. 
Where has she gone whose image you once reflected?

column1: なき人のかげだに見えずつれなくて心をやれるいさらゐの水
column2:
We see the image no more. How is it that 
These pools among the rocks yet seem so happy?

column1: そのかみの老い木はむべも朽ちぬらむうへし小松も苔生ひにけり
column2:
The ancient pine is gone. That need not surprise us―
For see how gnarled and mossy is its seedling.

column1: いづれをも陰とぞ頼む二葉より根ざしかはせる松のすゑすゑ
column2:
I now am shaded by two splendid trees 
Whose roots were intertwined when they were seedlings.

column1: 色まさるまがきの菊もをりをりに袖うちかけし秋を恋ふらし
column2:
Though time has deepened the hue of the bloom at the hedge, 
I do not forget how sleeve brushed sleeve that autumn.

column1: むらさきの雲にまがへる菊の花にごりなき世の星かとぞ見る
column2:
A purple cloud is this chrysanthemum, 
A beacon star which shines upon us all.

column1: 秋をへて時雨ふりぬる里人もかゝる紅葉のをりをこそ見ね
column2:
This aged peasant has known many autumn showers 
And not before seen finer autumn colors.

column1: 世の常の紅葉とや見るいにしへのためしにひける庭の錦を
column2:
Think you these the usual autumn colors? 
Our garden brocade imitates an earlier one.

column1: さしながらむかしをいまにつたふれば玉の小櫛ぞ神さびにける
column2:
I fear these little combs are scarred and worn. 
I have used them to summon back an ancient day.

column1: さしつぎに見る物にもがよろづ世をつげの小櫛の神さぶるまで
column2:
I only hope that she may be as you, 
All through the myriad years of the boxwood comb.

column1: 若葉さす野辺の小松を引きつれてもとの岩根をいのるけふかな
column2:
I come to pray that the rock may long endure 
And I bring with me the seedling pines from the field.

column1: 小松原末のよはひに引かれてや野辺の若菜も年をつむべき
column2:
Long shall be the life of the seedling pines―
To add to the years of the herbs brought in from the fields?

column1: 目に近く移ればかはる世の中を行すゑとをくたのみけるかな
column2:
I had grown so used to thinking it would not change. 
And now, before my very eyes, it changes.

column1: 命こそ絶ゆとも絶えめさだめなき世の常ならぬ中の契を
column2:
Life must end. It is a transient world. 
The one thing lasting is the bond between us.

column1: 中道をへだつるほどはなけれども心みだるゝけさのあわ雪
column2:
Not heavy enough to block the way between us. 
The flurries of snow this morning yet distress me.

column1: はかなくてうはの空にぞ消えぬべき風にたゞよふ春のあわ雪
column2:
You do not come I fain would disappear, 
A veil of snow upon the rough spring winds.

column1: 背きにしこの世にのこる心こそ入る山道のほだしなりけれ
column2:
Deep into these mountains I would go, 
But thoughts of one I leave still pull me back.

column1: 背く世のうしろめたくはさりがたきほだしをしゐてかけなはなれそ
column2:
If your thoughts are upon the world you leave behind, 
You should not make a point of cutting your ties.

column1: 年月を中にへだてて逢坂のさもせきがたく落つる涙か
column2:
So many years, and we meet at Meeting Barrier. 
A barrier it remains, but not to my tears.

column1: 涙のみせきとめがたき清水にて行あふ道ははやく絶えにき
column2:
Though tears may flow as the spring at Meeting Hill, 
The road between us was long ago blocked off.

column1: 沈みしも忘れぬものをこりずまに身もなげつべきやどの藤なみ
column2:
I have not forgotten the depths into which I plunged, 
And now these waves of wisteria seek to engulf me.

column1: 身を投げんふちもまことのふちならでかけじやさらにこりずまの浪
column2:
No waves at all of which to be so fearful. 
My heart, unchastened, sends out waves to join them.

column1: 身に近く秋やきぬらん見るまゝに青葉の山もうつろひにけり
column2:
I detect a change in the green upon the hills. 
Is autumn coming to them? Is it coming to me?

column1: 水鳥の青葉は色もかはらぬを萩の下こそけしきことなれ
column2:
No change do we see in the white of the waterfowl. 
Not so constant the lower leaves of the hagi.

column1: 老の波かひある浦にたち出でてしほたるゝあまをたれかとがめむ
column2:
Old waves come upon a friendly shore. 
A nun's sleeves dripping brine―who can object?

column1: しほたるゝあまを浪路のしるべにてたづねも見ばや浜の苫屋を
column2:
The weeping nun must take me over the waves 
To the reed-roofed cottage there upon the strand.

column1: 世を捨てて明石の浦にすむ人も心の闇ははるけしもせじ
column2:
An old man leaves the world, and in his heart 
Is darkness yet, * there on the Akashi strand.

column1: 光出でんあか月ちかくなりにけりいまぞ見し世の夢がたりする
column2:
The dawn is at hand. The radiance soon will pour forth. 
I turn from it to speak of an ancient dream.

column1: いかなれば花に木伝ふ鴬の桜をわきてねぐらとはせぬ
column2:
The generous warbler, moving from tree to tree. 
Neglects the cherry alone among them all.

column1: 深山木にねぐらさだむるはこ鳥もいかでか花の色にあくべき
column2:
The cuckoo building its nest in mountain depths 
Does not, be assured, neglect the cherry blossom.

column1: よそに見ておらぬなげきはしげれどもなごり恋しき花の夕かげ
column2:
The trees of sorrow seem denser from near at hand. 
And my yearning grows for those blossoms in the twilight.

column1: いまさらに色にな出でそ山桜をよばぬ枝に心かけきと
column2:
Do not let it be known. I pray of you, 
That your eye has fallen on the mountain cherry.

column1: 恋わぶる人のかたみと手ならせばなれよなにとてなく音なるらむ
column2:
You are here to remind me of someone I long for,
and what is it you long for yourself?

column1: たれか又心を知りて住吉の神世をへたる松にこととふ
column2:
You and I remember―and who else? 
Only we can address these godly pines.

column1: 住の江をいけるかひあるなぎさとは年ふるあまもけふや知るらん
column2:
The aged fisherwife knows as not before 
That Sumiyoshi is a place of joy.

column1: むかしこそまづ忘られね住吉の神のしるしを見るにつけても
column2:
It is a day I never shall forget. 
This god of Sumiyoshi brings me joy.

column1: 住の江の松に夜深くをく霜は神のかけたる木綿鬘かも
column2:
So white these pines with frost in the dead of night. 
Bedecked with sacred strands by the god himself?

column1: 神人の手にとりもたる榊葉に木綿かけそふるふかき夜の霜
column2:
Deep in the night the frost has added strands 
To the sacred branches with which we make obeisance.

column1: 祝り子が木綿うちまがひをく霜はげにいちしるき神のしるしか
column2:
So white the frost, one takes it for sacred strands 
And sees in it a sign of the holy blessing.

column1: おきてゆく空も知られぬあけぐれにいづくの露のかかる袖なり
column2:
I arise and go forth in the dark before the dawn. 
I know not where, nor whence came the dew on my sleeve.

column1: あけぐれの空にうき身は消えななん夢なりけりと見てもやむべく
column2:
Would I might fade away in the sky of dawn, 
And all of it might vanish as a dream.

column1: くやしくぞつみをかしけるあふひ草神のゆるせるかざしならぬに
column2:
In secret, without leave, she brings this heartvine, 
A most lamentable thing, a blasphemous thing.

column1: もろかづら落葉をなににひろひけむ名はむつましきかざしなれども
column2:
Laurel branches twain, so near and like. 
Why was it that I took the fallen leaf?

column1: わが身こそあらぬさまなれそれながら空おぼれするきみは君也。
column2:
I am horribly changed, and you pretend not to know me. 
You are the same.

column1: 消えとまるほどやは経べきたまさかにはちすの露のかかる許を
column2:
It is a life in which we cannot be sure 
Of lasting as long as the dew upon the lotus.

column1: 契をかむこの世ならでもはちす葉に玉ゐる露の心へだつな
column2:
To be as close as the drops of dew on the lotus 
Must be our promise in this world and the next.

column1: 夕露に袖ぬらせとやひぐらしの鳴くを聞く聞くおきて行らむ
column2:
The voice of the evening cicada says you must leave. 
'Be moist with evening dews,' you say to my sleeves?

column1: 待つ里もいかゞ聞くらんかたかたに心さはがすひぐらしの声
column2:
How do you think it sounds in yonder village, 
The cicada that summons me there and summons me here?

column1: あまの世をよそに聞かめや須磨の浦に藻塩たれしもたれならなくに
column2:
I should not care that now you are a nun? 
My sleeves were wet at Suma―because of you!

column1: あま舟にいかゞは思ひをくれけん明石の浦にいさりせし君
column2:
How comes it that the fisherman of Akashi 
Has let the boat make off to sea without him?

column1: いまはとて燃えむ煙もむすぼほれ絶えぬ思ひのなをや残らむ
column2:
My thoughts of you: will they stay when I am gone 
Like smoke that lingers over the funeral pyre?

column1: 立ち添ひて消えやしなましうきことを思ひみだるる煙くらべに
column2:
I wish to go with you, that we may see 
Whose smoldering thoughts last longer, yours or mine.

column1: 行くゑなき空の煙となりぬとも思ふあたりを立ちは離れじ
column2:
As smoke I shall rise uncertainly to the heavens, 
And yet remain where my thoughts will yet remain.

column1: たが世にか種はまきしと人とはばいかがいはねの松はこたへん
column2:
Should someone come asking when the seed was dropped, 
What shall it answer, the pine among the rocks?

column1: 時しあればかはらぬ色ににほひけりかたへ枯れにし宿の桜も
column2:
Although a branch of this cherry tree has withered, 
It bursts into new bloom as its season comes.

column1: この春は柳の芽にぞ玉はぬく咲き散る花の行くゑ知らねば
column2:
The willow shoots this spring,not knowing where
The petals may have fallen,are wet with dew.

column1: 木の下のしづくに濡れてさかさまに霞の衣着たる春かな
column2:
Drenched by the fall from these trees, I mourn for a child 
Who should in the natural order have mourned for me.

column1: 亡き人も思はざりけんうち捨てて夕べの霞君着たれとは
column2:
I doubt that he who left us wished it so, 
That you should wear the misty robes of evening.

column1: うらめしや霞の衣たれ着よと春よりさきに花の散りけん
column2:
Bitter, bitter―whom can he have meant 
To wear the misty robes ere the advent of spring?

column1: ことならばならしの枝にならさなむ葉守の神のゆるしありきと
column2:
By grace of the tree god let the branch so close 
To the branch that withered be close to the branch that lives.

column1: 柏木に葉守の神はまさずとも人ならすべき宿の梢か
column2:
There may not be a god protecting the oak. 
Think not, even so, its branches of easy access.

column1: 世を別れ入りなむ道はをくるともおなじところを君もたづねよ
column2:
Away from the world, you follow after me, 
And may we soon arrive at the same destination.

column1: 憂き世にはあらぬところのゆかしくて背く山路に思ひこそ入れ
column2:
Longing for a place not of this world, 
May I not join you in your mountain dwelling?

column1: 憂き節も忘れずながらくれ竹のこは捨てがたき物にぞありける
column2:
We cannot forget unpleasant associations. 
We do not discard the young bamboo even so.

column1: ことに出でて言はぬも言ふにまさるとは人にはぢたるけしきをぞ見る
column2:
There is a shyness which is more affecting 
Than any sound of word or sound of koto.

column1: 深き夜のあはればかりは聞きわけどこと寄りがほにえやは弾きける
column2:
I feel the sadness, in the autumn night. 
How can I speak of it if not through the koto?

column1: 露しげき葎の宿にいにしへの秋にかはらぬ虫の声かな
column2:
The voices of insects are unchanged this autumn, 
Rank though the grasses be round my dewy lodging.

column1: 横笛の調べはことにかはらぬをむなしくなりし音こそつきせね
column2:
The melody is as it always was. 
The voices that mourn are inexhaustible.

column1: 笛竹に吹きよる風のことならば末の世ながき音に伝へなむ
column2:
If it matters not which wind sounds the bamboo flute, 
Then let its note be forever with my children.

column1: 蓮葉をおなじ台と契をきて露のわかるゝけふぞかなしき
column2:
Separate drops of dew on the leaf of the lotus, 
We vow that we will be one, on the lotus to come.

column1: へだてなく蓮の宿を契りても君が心やすまじとすらむ
column2:
Together, you say, in the lotus dwelling to come. 
But may you not have certain reservations?

column1: 大方の秋をばうしと知りにしをふり捨てがたき鈴虫の声
column2:
The autumn is a time of deprivation. 
I have thought―and yet have loved this cricket.

column1: 心もて草のやどりをいとへどもなを鈴虫の声ぞふりせぬ
column2:
Although it has chosen to leave its grassy dwelling, 
It cannot, this lovely insect, complain of neglect.

column1: 雲の上をかけはなれたる住みかにももの忘れせぬ秋の夜の月
column2:
It does not forget, the moon of the autumn night, 
A comer remote from that realm above the clouds.

column1: 月影はおなじ雲居に見えながらわが宿からの秋ぞかはれる
column2:
In your cloud realm the moonlight is as always, 
And here we see that autumn means neglect.

column1: 山里のあはれをそふるタ霧に立ち出でん空もなき心ちして
column2:
An evening mist―how shall I find my way?―
Makes sadder yet a lonely mountain village.

column1: 山がつのまがきをこめて立つ霧も心そらなる人はとじめず
column2:
The mists which enshroud this rustic mountain fence 
Concern him only who is loathe to go.

column1: われのみやうき世を知れるためしにて濡れそふ袖の名を朽たすべき
column2:
Weeping and weeping, paraded before the world, 
The one and only model of haplessness?

column1: 大方はわれ濡れ衣を着せずとも朽ちにし袖の名やは隠るゝ
column2:
Had I not come inspiring all these tears, 
The world would not have noticed your misfortunes?

column1: おぎはらや軒端の露にそぼちつゝ八重立つ霧を分けぞゆくべき
column2:
Wet by dew-laden reeds beneath your eaves, 
I now push forth into the eightfold mists?

column1: 分けゆかむ草葉の露をかことにてなを濡れ衣をかけんとや思ふ
column2:
Because these dewy grasses wet your sleeves 
I too shall have wet sleeves-is that your meaning?

column1: たましいをつれなき袖にとゞめをきてわが心からまどはるゝかな
column2:
My heart is there in the sleeve of an unkind lady, 
Quite without my guidance. I am helpless.

column1: せくからに浅さぞ見えん山河の流れての名をつゝみはてずは
column2:
Shallow it is, for all these efforts to dam it. 
You cannot dam and conceal so famous a flow.

column1: 女郎花しほるゝ野辺をいづことて一夜ばかりの宿を借りけむ
column2:
You stay a single night. It means no more, 
This field of sadly fading maiden flowers?

column1: 秋の野の草のしげみは分けしかどかり寝の枕むすびやはせし
column2:
Although I made my way through thick autumn grasses, 
I wove no pillow of grass for vagrant sleep.

column1: あはれをもいかに知りてかなぐさめむあるや恋しき亡きやかなしき
column2:
Which emotion demands my sympathy, 
Grief for the one or longing for the other?

column1: いづれとか分きてながめん消えかへる露も草葉の上と見ぬ世を
column2:
I do not know the answer to your question. 
The dew does not rest long upon the leaves.

column1: 里とをみ小野の篠原わけて来てわれもしかこそ声もおしまね
column2:
I push my way through tangled groves to Ono. 
Shall my laments, O stag, be softer than yours?

column1: 藤衣露けき秋の山人は鹿の鳴く音に音をぞそへつる
column2:
Dew-drenched wisteria robes* in autumn mountains. 
Sobs to join the baying of the stag.

column1: 見し人の影すみはてぬ池水にひとり宿もる秋の夜の月
column2:
No shadows now of them whom once I knew. 
Only the autumn moon to guard the waters.

column1: いつとかはおどろかすべき明けぬ夜の夢さめてとか言ひしひとこと
column2:
Waking from the dream of an endless night 
You said―and when may I pay my visit?

column1: 朝タになく音をたつる小野山はたえぬ涙やをとなしの滝
column2:
Morning and night, laments sound over Mount Ono 
And Silent Waterfall―a flow of tears?

column1: のぼりにし峰の煙にたちまじり思はぬ方になびかずもがな
column2:
My choice would be to rise with the smoke from the peaks, 
Which might perhaps not go in a false direction.

column1: 恋しさのなぐさめがたきかたみにて涙にくもる玉の箱かな
column2:
A small bejeweled box, now wet with tears, 
To help me remember and seek elusive solace.

column1: うらみわび胸あきがたき冬の夜にまた鎖しまさる関の岩門
column2:
My sorrows linger as the winter night. 
The stony barrier gate is as slow to open.

column1: なるゝ身をうらむるよりは松島のあまの衣にたちやかへまし
column2:
I do not complain that I am used and rejected. 
Let me but go and join them at Matsushima.

column1: 松島のあまの濡衣なれぬとて脱ぎかへつてふ名を立ためやは
column2:
Robes of Matsushima, soggy and worn, 
For even them you may be held to account.

column1: ちぎりあれや君を心にとゞめをきてあはれと思ふうらめしと聞く
column2:
A bond from another life yet holds us together? 
Fond thoughts I have, disquieting reports.

column1: なにゆへか世に数ならぬ身ひとつをうしとも思ひかなしとも聞く
column2:
Disquieting reports, resentful thoughts―
Of one who does not matter in the least?

column1: 数ならば身に知られまし世のうさを人のためにも濡らす袖かな
column2:
The gloom I would know were I among those who matter 
I see from afar. I weep in sympathy.

column1: 人の世のうきをあはれと見しかども身にかへんとは思はざりしを
column2:
Many unhappy marriages I have seen, 
And never felt them as I feel my own.

column1: おしからぬこの身ながらも限りとて薪尽きなんことのかなしさ
column2:
I have no regrets as I bid farewell to this life. 
Yet the dying away of the fire is always sad.

column1: 薪こる思ひはけふをはじめにてこの世に願ふ法ぞはるけき
column2:
Our prayers, the first of them borne in on brushwood, 
Shall last the thousand years of the Blessed One's toils.
